notes:
1. Newton's Second Law of Motion

The relationship between force, mass, and acceleration is given by Newton's Second Law. It states that the net force acting on a particle is equal to the product of its mass and acceleration.

$$ \mathbf{F} = m\mathbf{a} $$
  • $\mathbf{F}$: Net external force vector acting on the particle.
  • $m$: Mass of the particle (scalar).
  • $\mathbf{a}$: Acceleration vector.

2. Mass vs. Weight

It is crucial to distinguish between mass and weight. Mass ($m$) is a measure of an object's inertia or quantity of matter. Weight ($W$) is the force of gravity acting on that mass.

$$ W = mg $$

where $g$ is the acceleration due to gravity.

3. Units

  • SI Units: Mass is in kilograms (kg), acceleration in meters per second squared ($m/s^2$), and force in Newtons (N). $1 \text{ N} = 1 \text{ kg} \cdot \text{m/s}^2$. Gravity $g \approx 9.81 \text{ m/s}^2$.
  • US Customary Units: This system can be confusing. Force is typically in pounds-force (lbf) or kips. Acceleration is in $ft/s^2$. Gravity $g \approx 32.2 \text{ ft/s}^2$. Mass is technically measured in slugs. $$ m [\text{slugs}] = \frac{W [\text{lbf}]}{g [\text{ft/s}^2]} = \frac{W}{32.2} $$ Therefore, $1 \text{ lbf} = 1 \text{ slug} \cdot 1 \text{ ft/s}^2$.

solvedExamples.question: An object weighs 100 lbf on Earth. What is its mass in slugs?
solvedExamples.explanation: Mass in slugs is calculated by dividing the weight in pounds-force by the acceleration of gravity in $ft/s^2$. $m = W/g = 100 \text{ lbf} / 32.2 \text{ ft/s}^2 \approx 3.105$ slugs.

solvedExamples.question: A net force of 50 N is applied to a 10 kg block. What is the acceleration of the block?
solvedExamples.explanation: Using Newton's Second Law, $F = ma$. Rearranging for acceleration: $a = F/m = 50 \text{ N} / 10 \text{ kg} = 5 \text{ m/s}^2$.

solvedExamples.question: Which of the following is a unit of mass in the US Customary system?
solvedExamples.explanation: The slug is the standard unit of mass in the US Customary system. It is defined as the mass that accelerates by 1 ft/s² when acted upon by a force of 1 lbf. The pound-force and kip are units of force.
